data.text:
Hey there! I‚Äôm an engineering manager based in Ireland. I‚Äôve worked on products that help people with business intelligence, data visualisation, UX as a Service, billing, and eCommerce. I‚Äôve built and managed co-located and distributed global teams. Empathy is at the heart of my role as a manager.

This article is a personal one. I‚Äôm writing as an individual, not a manager. It‚Äôs not only for people managers this time - it‚Äôs for everyone. It‚Äôs not a tidy checklist like the articles I‚Äôve shared before; I can‚Äôt promise to reliably help you detect burnout in your team or company. Rather, I hope this article will help you recognise and prevent burnout in yourself, and maybe others. My overarching aim is to help break down the stigma surrounding mental health.

I wanted to focus on burnout as a topic, agnostic of any company I‚Äôve worked in, so there won‚Äôt be any circumstantial details. Suffice to say, specifically in the tech industry, we are largely responsible for our own circumstances. It‚Äôs up to us to bring about change by doing some or all of the following: push back, ask for help, book sick days, or leave. Your workplace may also have support systems in place for mental health that you can consider using.

What Is Burnout? üî•

Mayo Clinic defines burnout as:

‚Äú[..]a special type of work-related stress ‚Äî a state of physical or emotional exhaustion that also involves a sense of reduced accomplishment and loss of personal identity.‚Äù Source

Burnout can manifest itself in physical and mental symptoms. It has real effects on your health. Popular medical sites such as WebMD and Mayo Clinic list symptoms and further information.

For a more fully fledged description with real life examples, watch this talk by James Spivey titled Let‚Äôs Talk About Burnout. James is one of my management role models - I‚Äôm lucky enough to have worked with him. When I burned out most recently, I re-watched his talk and reached out to him. That resulted in me finally taking concrete actions to help myself.

Sadly, I have experienced burnout multiple times in my career. I‚Äôve experienced the following symptoms (which may or may not apply to others):

Extreme fatigue/exhaustion

Insomnia

Depression

Panic attacks

Otherwise unexplained body aches (i.e. not caused by exercise or injury)

Otherwise unexplained headaches

Difficulty concentrating

Less clinical symptoms, sprinkled with some humblebragging, because I don't do it enough üíÉ:

I stopped reading books - I read on average 55 books per year. That‚Äôs almost one a week. Not constantly reading is very unusual for me.

I stopped learning languages - I broke my Duolingo (language learning app) streak of 205 days. I was aiming for one year :(

With the benefit of hindsight, I understand now that my energy for the above activities was literally sapped from me.

What Burnout Taught Me

Your company is not your family

Do not think of your company as your family. The hard truth is that companies are businesses, and the goal of a business is to make money - often at any (legal) cost. I will dedicate a future article on exploring how to redefine this purpose and make it more ethical - however, for now:

Think of your colleagues, peers, and friends as allies. People don‚Äôt need to be blood-related to be supportive and caring to each other. It can just make it more complicated when they are.

Tell your story, ask for help, and brainstorm solutions together. You never know how you could help others, or yourself, simply by sharing.

If you observe or suspect that someone else is struggling, reach out. We‚Äôre all humans at the end of the day. Let‚Äôs support each other. As an example, I‚Äôve found my managers to be very understanding and supportive after I opened up to them.

Tell someone about it

After I opened up to others, they encouraged me to take time off and do other things to recover and look after myself. Not many people talk about it openly, but I‚Äôm convinced that in our increasingly fast-paced society, nevermind being in the midst of a global pandemic, almost everyone has experienced burnout by now and will understand more than you might expect. Some starting points:

Tell your manager or colleagues that you‚Äôre burned out and to expect some downtime. Maybe they can cover some of your responsibilities in the meantime.

Tell your manager and let them help you.

Tell your peers what‚Äôs going on and encourage them to do the same so you can collectively improve your work culture.

Tell your loved ones and chosen family. Let them support you if they are able to.

Most importantly: seek professional help if needed.

Delete any apps used for work communication from your phone

It‚Äôs in my nature to care deeply about my company, our mission, my team, and my colleagues. I would compulsively check Slack after work, on vacation, and when I couldn‚Äôt sleep. This further erodes the tenuous separation we have between work and life.

Unless you truly work in a mission critical, real time role (I find it helpful to compare my job to emergency services or air traffic control), few things are important enough that they can‚Äôt wait until the next day. I knew about this guideline and espoused it in front of others, but did not uphold it for myself. Simply deleting Slack from my phone gave me back mental space - much more than I expected.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just software.‚Äù - a delivery manager I worked with

Work to live, don‚Äôt live to work

Work is not worth burning out for. It‚Äôs not worth sacrificing your health or life for someone else's business. You have a life, family, hobbies, interests, and value outside of work. Do not let your job define your life or identity.

Remember the top five regrets of the dying? Not a single person said ‚ÄúI wish I had worked more‚Äù. In fact, they said quite the opposite.

‚ÄúOne of the symptoms of an approaching nervous breakdown is the belief that one‚Äôs work is terribly important.‚Äù - Bertrand Russell

Use sick leave

If you have paid sick leave available, use it. Burnout is a sickness that can deeply affect you mentally as well as physically. Don‚Äôt feel the need to justify how it‚Äôs the same as having the flu, a stomach bug, or a broken leg: I‚Äôm here to tell you that it‚Äôs the same. People don‚Äôt leave jobs after the flu, but it can be a consequence of sustained burnout.

If you are a people manager or HR, make sure your colleagues are aware of any available sick leave, so they can take advantage of it.

Consider deleting social media apps from your phone

This is not strictly related to work, but phenomena such as doomscrolling and revenge bedtime procrastination have real effects on health that are recognised by psychologists. I deleted Instagram from my phone, my go-to procrastination scroller. That combined with deleting Slack helped improve my focus and concentration.

Finish working at a reasonable time

It will depend on your working arrangement. There is very little to gain by either you or your company if you literally burn all of your energy and health working late. Moreover, it sets a bad precedent for your team and general culture, as others will feel like they also have to work late. This can be extremely difficult or impossible for parents and carers.

There are times when it makes sense to go above and beyond, but do not make that the norm. Don‚Äôt create or contribute to a toxic culture.

Takeaways ü•°

I hope this article was informative and helpful. Here‚Äôs a summary of the points I made:

Your company is not your family.

Tell someone if you suspect you are burning out, or are already burned out.

Delete any apps used for work communication from your phone.

Work to live, don‚Äôt live to work.

Use sick leave if available.

Consider deleting social media apps from your phone.

Stop working at a reasonable time.

Let‚Äôs take care of ourselves, so we can take care of each other.

---

As always, feel free to share any feedback in the comments. If you are struggling and don‚Äôt know where to turn, I‚Äôm happy to message you to try and help - just let me know in a comment.
